;
;;Paul Simon 于 2021 年在纽约中央公园表演。有关他职业生涯的新纪录片《不安的梦想》：保罗·西蒙的音乐于周日在多伦多国际电影节上首映。
;

;保罗·西蒙表示，他“开始”接受左耳几乎完全丧失听力的情况，这对他的听力造成了影响他现场表演音乐的能力。

;

;这位 81 岁的创作歌手在;多伦多国际电影节上的《不安的梦想：保罗·西蒙的音乐》;。

;

;“我还没有完全接受它， “但我已经开始这么做了，”西蒙在放映后的问答中与纪录片导演亚历克斯·吉布尼一起告诉观众。

;

;“我每天都弹吉他。它是让我创造性地表达自己的工具。但这也是我寻求安慰的地方。如果我感觉……“无论如何”。所以这对我来说是非常重要的事情。你知道，当你患有某种残疾时，你就会发生一些事情，改变你的意识或改变你与生活互动的方式。”

;

;他说没有任何改善;自从他五月份首次透露听力损失以来;。< /p>;

;

;;相关：;;保罗·西蒙：《七首诗篇》评论——一个惊喜和一个启示;

;
;

;“通常，当我完成一张专辑时，我会带着它出去巡演，然后然后我就有机会真正调查这件作品。然后它演变成另一个标准，并走得更远，”西蒙说。

;

;“尽管从现在起一周后，我将尝试与两位吉他手合作，他们将演奏我在录下来，看看我能不能唱这首曲子。我不知道如何才能将我的声音与吉他融为一体。”他补充道。

;

;五月份，西蒙透露在为;他的最新专辑《七首诗篇》。;

;

;“突然间，我的左耳失去了大部分听力，没有人能对此做出解释，”他说。 “所以一切都变得更加困难。”

;

;他说他最感到的是“沮丧和烦恼”，而不是愤怒，“因为我认为一切都会过去，它会自行修复”。他还表示，这改变了他对表演某些“我不想再现场演唱”的歌曲的想法。

;

;“有时有些歌曲是我喜欢的，然后在巡演的某个时刻，我会说，‘你他妈在做什么，保罗？’”他说。 “这种情况经常发生在; ;《你可以叫我阿尔》期间。我会想，‘你在做什么？你就像保罗·西蒙翻唱乐队。你应该离开马路，回家去。'”

;

;著名导演吉布尼，他还执导了山达基教纪录片《大白于天下》、《安然：房间里最聪明的人》和《Mea Maxima Culpa：上帝殿中的沉默》在他最新的纪录片《不安的梦想》中，他将目光转向了西蒙六年的职业生涯。这部时长三个半小时的影片讲述了这位音乐家;;与儿时好友阿特·加芬克尔 (Art Garfunkel) 在《西蒙与加芬克尔》中度过的时光、他 1986 年热门个人专辑《Graceland》的录制，以及他晚年在他的专辑《Graceland》中的录音。位于德克萨斯州的家庭工作室。

;

;《不安的梦》的总体上映日期尚未公布，但将于 10 月在伦敦电影节上放映。

; Tue, 12 Sep 2023 11:22:01 +0800 Philippine Nobel prize winner Maria Ressa acquitted of tax chargeshttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/sep/12/philippine-nobel-prize-winner-maria-ressa-acquitted-of-tax-charges
;;2023-09-12T02:26:19Z;
;
;;菲律宾记者兼诺贝尔奖获得者 Maria Ressa 抵达法庭时挥手致意。
;

;菲律宾诺贝尔奖获得者玛丽亚·雷萨 (Maria Ressa) 的最后一项逃税指控被无罪释放，这是这位资深记者的最新法律胜利，她之前曾将这些案件描述为骚扰模式的一部分，但她正在努力避免入狱。

;

;这位 59 岁的女士于 2021 年获得诺贝尔和平奖，多年来一直在对抗时任总统罗德里戈·杜特尔特 (Rodrigo Duterte) 执政期间提出的多项指控。

;

;雷萨 (Ressa) 是杜特尔特和杜特尔特的直言不讳的批评者。长期以来，她一直坚称针对她和她于 2012 年共同创立的新闻网站 Rappler 的案件是出于政治动机。

;

;“你必须有信心，”雷萨在法庭外对记者说。无罪释放后的法庭。

;
;

;;相关：;;诺贝尔奖得主 Maria Ressa 表示牛津研究所的研究可用于对付记者;

;
;

;Ressa 和 Rappler 因 2015 年出售菲律宾存托凭证而面临五项逃税指控，这是公司从外国投资者筹集资金的一种方式。

;

;;一月份，法院宣告他们四项指控无罪。< /a>; 第五起案件由另一家法院审理，周二，她和 Rappler 被宣告无罪。

;

;尽管无罪释放，Ressa 和 Rappler 在另外两起法庭案件中面临着不确定的未来。 Ressa 和前同事 Rey Santos Jr 正在对网络诽谤罪提出上诉，该罪名被判处近七年监禁。

;

;与此同时，Rappler 正在对菲律宾证券交易委员会因涉嫌违反规定而关闭的命令提出质疑。禁止外资拥有媒体。根据宪法，对媒体的投资仅限于菲律宾公民或公民控制的实体。

;

;此案源自 eBay 创始人皮埃尔·奥米迪亚 (Pierre Omidyar) 建立的美国奥米迪亚网络 (Omidyar Network) 2015 年的一项投资。 Omidyar Network 后来将其对 Rappler 的投资转移给了该网站的当地管理人员，以阻止杜特尔特关闭该网站的努力。

;

;尽管还存在一些障碍，但 Ressa 周二仍表现出一贯的挑衅和乐观态度，告诉记者最新的无罪释放“坚定了我们继续维持司法系统的决心”。

;

;“这表明法院系统正在发挥作用，我们希望看到其余指控被驳回，”她说。

;

;Ressa 和 Rappler 的法律麻烦始于2016年杜特尔特当选，他经常对批评者发起脏话攻击。杜特尔特政府声称与针对雷萨的任何案件无关。

;

;另一位备受瞩目的杜特尔特批评者、人权活动家莱拉·德利马 (Leila de Lima)，;因贩毒指控而入狱六年多;

;

;在针对她的竞选活动中，身为美国公民的雷萨一直留在菲律宾。她正在保释，等待针对网络诽谤定罪的上诉，当她想要出国旅行时，需要申请法院批准。

;

;;雷萨和俄罗斯记者德米特里·穆拉托夫因“捍卫自由”的努力而共同荣获诺贝尔奖;

;

;2022 年 6 月接替杜特尔特的菲律宾总统费迪南德·马科斯此前曾表示，他不会干涉雷萨的案件，理由是政府行政部门和司法部门之间权力分离。

; Tue, 12 Sep 2023 10:52:01 +0800 Man dies in Grand Canyon national park while attempting grueling hikehttps://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/sep/11/grand-canyon-national-park-hike-death-extreme-heat

;
;;亚利桑那州大峡谷南缘全景。
;

;A 55-公园管理局官员宣布，周六，一名 7 岁的男子在大峡谷国家公园徒步旅行时死亡。

;

;这名徒步旅行者名叫 Ranjith Varma，来自弗吉尼亚州马纳萨斯，在尝试从南部徒步 18 英里时死亡峡谷边缘至北缘。瓦尔马和六人一起徒步旅行，在徒步穿越内峡谷（徒步旅行最低部分）的一半时，他变得没有反应。根据国家公园管理局 (NPS) 的新闻稿，紧急救援人员被召集，旁观者开始进行心肺复苏。

;
;

;;相关：;;菲尼克斯在地狱般炎热的夏季创下纪录 - 但缓解在望;

;
;

;救援人员驾驶直升机前往该地区，但试图对他进行复苏，但没有成功。

;

;“这绝对是一个悲惨的情况。 NPS 公共事务专家乔尔·贝尔德 (Joelle Baird) 表示：“没有人来到大峡谷时会想到会发生这样的事情。”

;

;瓦尔马正在前往峡谷边缘的最后一段路程。 rim' 徒步旅行，这是一次艰苦的旅程，可能需要 12 至 15 小时，海拔会上升数千英尺。每个路段都有独特的海拔、温度和景观，使得徒步旅行对于没有做好准备或没有先进行身体调理的人来说异常严格和危险。

;

;虽然目前还不清楚 Varma 的确切死因是什么贝尔德强调，这次徒步旅行的严格性加上最近的热浪使得现在尝试这样的行动是一个危险的时刻。 Varma徒步旅行当天，峡谷内部的气温超过100华氏度。

;

;“人们需要适应环境。贝尔德说：“炎热可能是让很多人措手不及的一个因素，除非他们来自炎热的环境。”

;

;瓦尔玛是近几个月在国家公园死亡的几人之一。极端高温席卷了从加利福尼亚州到佛罗里达州的美国各州，并影响了全国几乎所有 425 个国家公园。

;

;7 月初，一名 57 岁的妇女在大峡谷徒步旅行时死亡。 6 月 23 日，一对父亲和继子在 119 华氏度（48 摄氏度）的高温下徒步旅行后在德克萨斯州大本德国家公园双双死亡。在死亡谷，有两人死亡，其中一名 71 岁男子于 7 月 18 日在黄金峡谷徒步旅行后倒下，另一名 65 岁男子被发现死于车内，死于“明显的中暑”。

;

;大峡谷应急人员接到约 350 个搜救电话。贝尔德说，这些救援的两个主要因素是“身体状况不佳和疲劳”。每年大约有 10 到 20 人死于峡谷，瓦尔玛是今年的第九个。

; Tue, 12 Sep 2023 09:52:01 +0800 Trump asks judge to recuse herself in federal 2020 election subversion casehttps://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/sep/11/trump-2020-election-subversion-case-judge-tanya-chutkan

;;唐纳德·特朗普于 9 月 6 日离开纽约市特朗普大厦。

;唐纳德·特朗普的法律团队周一要求负责监督针对他的 2020 年选举干预起诉的联邦法官将自己从该案中剔除，理由是她之前在前总统对 1 月 6 日国会大厦袭击事件负责后发表的公开评论是取消资格。

;美国宇航局的科学家宣布the existence of a possible rare water ocean on a giant exoplanet scores of light years away and also a chemical hint of a sign of potential life.

;
;

;;Related: ;;The story of light: Nasa discoveries reimagined – in pictures;

;
;

;The “intriguing” discovery was made by the space agency's James Webb telescope, peering 120 light years from Earth in the constellation Leo, building on earlier studies of the region using Webb's predecessors, Hubble and Kepler.

;

;Researchers have named the exoplanet K2-18 b, an unremarkable moniker for something with such potential significance. Almost nine times the mass of Earth, it is, Nasa, says: “a Hycean exoplanet, one which has the potential to possess a hydrogen-rich atmosphere and a water ocean-covered surface”.

;

;The space agency said that its observations of the chemical make-up of the planet's atmosphere suggested the possibility of an ocean world. “The abundance of methane and carbon dioxide, and shortage of ammonia, support the hypothesis that there may be a water ocean underneath a hydrogen-rich atmosphere in K2-18 b,” it said.

;

;But the agency also hinted at even more remarkable possibility in the potential finding of a molecule called dimethyl sulfide (DMS), which on Earth is only produced by life.

;

;“The bulk of the DMS in Earth's atmosphere is emitted from phytoplankton in marine environments,” the Nasa press release said.

;

;The presence of DMS, however, is still to be confirmed, and requires further investigation. “Upcoming Webb observations should be able to confirm if DMS is indeed present in the atmosphere of K2-18 b at significant levels,” said Nikku Madhusudhan, a University of Cambridge astronomer and lead author of the Nasa research.

;

;It would not be the first time Nasa has found indications of water on other planets. Water vapor was previously discovered on the ;smaller exoplanet, HAT-P-11b;, roughly the size of Neptune in the constellation Cygnus, also 120 light years away.

;

;But scientists are excited by the revelation, even though they caution it does not necessarily mean the planet could support life.

;

;“Our findings underscore the importance of considering diverse habitable environments in the search for life elsewhere,” said Madhusudhan.

;

;“Traditionally, the search for life on exoplanets has focused primarily on smaller rocky planets, but the larger Hycean worlds are significantly more conducive to atmospheric observations.”

;

;Orbiting the cool dwarf star K2-18, the exoplanet, 2.6 times the radius of Earth, lies in what Nasa calls the ;habitable zone;, a region around a star where planets with liquid water may be present.

;

;Its interior likely contains a large mantle of high-pressure ice, similar to Neptune, Nasa says, but likely has a thinner hydrogen-rich atmosphere and an ocean surface. Hycean worlds are predicted to have oceans of water, but on K2-18 b it is also possible the ocean is too hot to be habitable.

;

;The planet's existence was first discovered by ;Nasa's K2 mission; in 2015, but Webb's improved technology over the earlier telescopes allowed for a more detailed analysis, and revelation it could be an ocean world. Scientists were able to study a tiny fraction of the star's light as it passed through the exoplanet's atmosphere.

;

;“This result was only possible because of the extended wavelength range and unprecedented sensitivity of Webb, which enabled robust detection of spectral features with just two transits,” Madhusudhan said.

;

;“For comparison, one transit observation with Webb provided comparable precision to eight observations with Hubble conducted over a few years and in a relatively narrow wavelength range.”

;

;Nasa celebrated the first anniversary of operation of the Webb space telescope in July by releasing an ;“unprecedented” closeup image; of the nearest star-forming region to Earth.

;

;In little more than a year, it has allowed humans to look closer towards the origins of the universe than ever before, and produced high-resolution pictures of far-distant worlds and the mysterious structures that surround them.

;

;They include the “rare and fleeting” phase of a ;star on the cusp of death;; early galaxies formed just ;350m years after the big bang;; and evidence of “;universe breaker galaxies;” far larger than scientists thought possible, with the potential to upend current theories of cosmology.

; Tue, 12 Sep 2023 05:52:02 +0800 MPs furious over being kept in dark about alleged spying for Chinahttps://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/sep/11/mps-furious-over-being-kept-in-dark-about-alleged-spying-for-china
;;2023-09-11T19:32:25Z;
;
;;Lindsay Hoyle addressing the Commons on Monday
;

;MPs have vented their fury over a six-month silence that followed an aide operating at the heart of parliament being arrested on suspicion of allegedly spying for China and accused of passing information to Beijing in breach of the Official Secrets Act.

;

;They voiced concern on Monday that the gap meant they had been unable to take their own security precautions, amid wider concern that individual pro-democracy activists could be put at risk by any security lapse.

;

;Kirsty Blackman, an SNP frontbencher, asked why parliament only learned about the allegations from media reports over the weekend, and called for “a review into the decision-making process” as soon as possible.

;

;Tim Loughton, a Conservative MP who has been previously sanctioned by China for criticising the country's regime, said no guidance had been provided to MPs by parliament's security authorities or by the Foreign Office or Home Office.

;

;Responding directly to Blackman, Lindsay Hoyle, the Commons speaker, said “the MPs who needed to be told were told” at the time of the arrest, which had quietly taken place in March.

;

;Investigators needed time to complete their inquiries, Hoyle added, describing the episode as “a major security issue”.

;

;The researcher, who is in his 20s, was arrested in Edinburgh at the same time as a second person, in their 30s. It is understood he had links to Tory MP Tom Tugendhat, until he became security minister, and subsequently Alicia Kearns, who chairs the foreign affairs select committee.

;

;Only a small number of MPs appear to have been warned, with other members of the cross-party foreign affairs select committee saying they had not been told about the arrest at the time.

;

;Police sources also confirmed to the Guardian that there had been no public report of the arrests at the time they were made.

;

;A handful of senior ministers were aware of the situation, however. Rishi Sunak, the prime minister, told parliament that James Cleverly, the foreign secretary, had raised the matter in private with his counterparts when he visited China at the end of August.

;

;“I'm limited in what I can say specifically, but I've been emphatically clear in our engagement with China that we will not accept any interference in our democracy and parliamentary system,” Sunak said.

;

;He added: “I can absolutely confirm that the foreign secretary raised these issues on his recent visit.”

;

;Parliament's security team is understood to have been “actively involved from the beginning” in the investigation, according to a senior parliamentary source. They said that the authorities worked with the security services to identify the parliamentary researcher who was arrested.

; ;

;The researcher is not being named by the Guardian for legal reasons and on Monday, without identifying himself, he released a statement denying that he was a spy.

;

;“It is vital that it is known that I am completely innocent,” he said in remarks released by his lawyers.

;

;“I have spent my career to date trying to educate others about the challenge and threats presented by the Chinese Communist party. To do what has been claimed against me in extravagant news reporting would be against everything I stand for.”

;

;The two men remain on police bail until an unspecified date in early October, while investigators continue to examine the case, which has prompted increased concerns about Beijing's willingness to spy on the UK.

;

;The parliamentary researcher arrested has no family ties to China. Security sources said on Monday that they believed the alleged spying could represent a potential escalation by Beijing of its espionage activities.

;

;“If this is proved to have happened once, it is not likely to be an isolated incident,” one former senior intelligence official said.

;

;China has accused Britain of engaging in “nothing but malicious slander” in its response to the news of the arrests. A spokesperson for the Chinese embassy in the UK complained of “anti-China political manipulation” and urged the British leaders to “stop putting on such self-staged political farce”.

;

;Luke de Pulford, the executive director of the ;Inter Parliamentary Alliance on China;, an international group of MPs and legislators monitoring human rights in the country, said those who knew the arrested researcher had not had a chance to reflect on the impact on any China-related cases they dealt with.

;

;“This guy was arrested in March, so people around them don't know what their potential exposure to risk is. That includes MPs who dealt with asylum requests or visa requests for people like those from Hong Kong, dissidents and others.

;

;“But we are also talking about people whose families are back home in China, but who are working here, and are doing work that would open them up to accusations on the part of the CCP of working with foreign forces, for which they could face long periods of imprisonment,” he said.

;

;Mark Sabah, UK and EU director of the ;Committee for Freedom in Hong Kong Foundation;, said he feared that pro-democracy activists who shared personal information with British MPs could be at risk if any information had leaked to Beijing.

;

;“The big issue here, though, is that it's not the MPs who suffer most from this, whether it's embarrassment, or the security or parliamentary screening team,” he said.

;

;“It's actually the people who make approaches to lobby for causes like Tibet, Hong Kong and others who have genuine threats from the Chinese Communist party and who are in need of genuine and safe channels they can use to advocate and feed information into the debate.”
